data.title: Tab double click to maximize editor of the tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8
- OS Version: Mac OS Sierra

Hello,

if I'm not wrong, by double clicking the tab it pins the file . Personally, I would prefer to expand the file editor / collapsing the menu on the left. It would be same behaviour as the File Explorer button on the top left. Is it possible? Or, can people customize the tab double click? 
People could set a pin option on each tab and the double click expands the file editor window.
Or, if simpler, set the option in a right click context menu on each tab. Isn't it?

Thanks a lot

Matteo

data.title: Add a few niceties for making Flatpak builds of VSCode
data.body:
This adds the following:

* Support signing built Flatpak builds using GnuPG.
* Support exporting Flatpak builds to a repository, which can be used for distributing the application *and* updates.
* When exporting to a repository, set the subject of the commit message for the repository to contain the built version.

## Rationale

Flatpak includes support for fetching applications from a repository (which may contain multiple applications and runtimes), and updates pushed to the repository are automatically picked by application managers like [GNOME Software](https://wiki.gnome.org/Apps/Software) or when using the `flatpak update` command. 

## More Info

Additional reasons why one would want to prefer a repository over serving a bunch of `.flatpak` files:

* Under the hood repositories are managed by [OSTree](https://github.com/ostreedev/ostree), which uses a [Git-like model to store data](https://ostree.readthedocs.io/en/latest/manual/repo/): each file is stored as blob, which gets hashed, and stored indexed by its hash —thus deduplicating data—, which makes repositories quite space efficient. If one is going to host multiple versions of Flatpak apps, a significative amount of disk space can be saved server-side.
* Repositories can be server over plain HTTP(S) as well — nothing special is needed server-side.
* When the `flatpak-builder` tool (called under the hood by the `flatpak-bundler` JS module) is building a `.flatpak` single-file bundle, it will first commit the built files into a temporary OSTree repository and then export that single commit to the `.flatpak` file. Using `$FLATPAK_REPO` just skips the latter.
* Installation is not made more complex for users. They can still download and just double-click to open a `.flatpakref` file in GNOME Software, which will have the application installed *and* the repository configured in one go. This is nice to ensure the users will get updates (see “Referring to repositories” in the [Flatpak documentation](http://flatpak.org/developer.html#Distributing_Applications) for details).

---

This is a follow-up to PR #16169 and a complement to issue #7112.

data.title: Add an AppData XML data file to Linux builds
data.body:
The [AppData](https://people.freedesktop.org/~hughsient/appdata/) files provide descriptive data about an application, and is typically used in application managers to display additional information to the user. Having an AppData file is especially important for some graphical application installers: without one, an application manager may not event show an entry for the application. This happens for example in GNOME Software.

For the sake of completeness, this commit not only adds the AppData file to the Flatpak build, but also to the Linux .deb and .rpm packages.

---

This is follow-up to PR #16169 and a complement to issue #7112.

data.title: [macOS] updating never works, loops forever
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0-insider 2abfc207828739bd5b10d0bb8dbfea13506cfc69 (also reproducible on stable, but easier to trigger here due to nightly updates)
- OS Version: Mac OS 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Extract the given build from code.visualstudio.com, move it into Applications
2. Launch the app, wait a bit
3. When VS prompts you that an update is available, "Update Now"

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/359239/21250177/6e8e54d4-c397-11e6-8d23-7674bb98a152.png)

4. The application closes, and never re-launches.

Launching the app manually has it at the original version.

Apologies for the lack of details, if there's specific log files I can give you around the update process let me know where to look.

data.title: ProtoType Go To Implementation For TypeScript
data.body:
For #10806

Initial prototype of using the TypeScript Go To Implementation Feature. Adds a go to implementation command for js and ts documents.

This has a few issues at the moment:

* We likely would want to expose `go to implementation` for other languages. Therefore, it would make sense to standardize an api for this based on the existing `DefinitionProvider` api.
* The location values that typescript returns are not correct some of the time. I'll double check that this is not a bug on our side, but the feature needs some more testing and polish before we can ship it.

data.title: typings.json schema is not working on vscode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0

From https://github.com/SchemaStore/schemastore/issues/257

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3254987/21248288/dd54a72c-c2ea-11e6-9bcb-efe52bd1bac6.png)

Could it because of `$schema` is ahead of `title`?
https://github.com/SchemaStore/schemastore/blob/master/src/schemas/json/typings.json#L2

Compare to others, (e.g. tsconfig.json), it's the other way around:
https://github.com/SchemaStore/schemastore/blob/master/src/schemas/json/tsconfig.json#L2

I understand that it's json and order should not matter, but I can't see other reason for it.
Can I make a PR to give it a try? Or do you know how to get a local copy and try it out?

data.title: API For Monitoring Editor Viewport Changes
data.body:
For #5047

Add an API for monitoring when the viewport (defined by at least the first visible line and last visible line) of a text editor changes. This could enable extension developers to synchronize scrolling between files, similar to how the diff view currently works. 

The viewport can change in a number of ways, including:

* Scrolling
* File editing
* Navigation

#5047 is for scrolling syntonization specifically, but I think we would likely want to handle any viewport changes in a uniform way.

Let me know if you have any thoughts on the API or potential use cases that we should consider when designing the API

data.title: Wrapping in Markdown Preview
data.body:
Fixes #15921

Improve the markdown preview's layout and handling of wrapping text:

* Use breakword by default to break up very long words
* When `editor.wordWrap` is enabled, wrap code blocks inside of the html preview.
* Reverts https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/41467b74b7e486f3a5857d3cc0ab15d85a2b7a84 . This change is adding an 20px margin to the left of any html content. I believe the html content itself should be responsible for adding this padding and should normally fill the entire screen.
* Better centers markdown preview content

@jrieken Can you take a look at the padding-left change and let me know if you have any concerns? Can we handle the case that commit intended to fix somehow else instead of adding padding to all webviews?

data.title: Inconsistency between files.insertFinalNewline and Format Document
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.0 (38746938a4ab94f2f57d9e1309c51fd6fb37553d, 2016-12-13T17:38:28.425Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|RelativePath|jakob101|0.8.0|
|copy-relative-path|alexdima|0.0.1|
|Theme-Dracula|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-TomorrowKit|ms-vscode|0.1.3|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set `files.insertFinalNewline` to `true`
2. Format Document on JSON file (likely several file types)--this removes the trailing newline
3. Save file--this adds back trailing newline

Format Document should take into consideration the `insertFinalNewline` option

data.title: Feature Request: Auto-trigger tasks before Git commit
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

We've always needed the ability to run predetermined tasks before a Git commit automatically. If we could auto-run tasks like this, we could automate build processes and other vital tasks when using client-side bundling tools like Webpack or other systems that we can't run in CI.

data.title: Hide sidebars first and then go to full screen when toggle Zen mode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-Insiders
- OS Version: macOS

Currently when we toggle Zen mode, the window goes to Full Screen mode first, which means the editor, activity bar and side bar become slightly larger in this period. Then we'll hide activity bar and side bar, then activity bar and side bar shrink to zero width and the editor becomes slightly larger again. IMHO, hiding activity bar and sidebars first and then go to Full Screen mode may make it more smooth as it looks like that the editor is becoming larger and eats all other parts of VS Code and the desktop.

data.title: Status bar is hidden in Zen mode, made VIM extension unusable
data.body:
I'm using [vscodevim.vim extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vscodevim.vim), which need status bar to indicate current mode, and input search terms.

I like the idea of Zen mode in 1.8, but it hides the status bar, and there is no way to get it back, which pretty much make VIM extension usable. Please add an option to keep status bar in Zen mode.

data.title: "find all references" previously highlighted "find all references" word remains highlighted
Issue with saving files on mounted drive: "Could not resolve any model with provided uri"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Mac OS X El Capitan

This issue seems to happen only for mounted drives (e.g. SSHFS a remote server to access files, and open the mounted folder with VSC). 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Visual Studio Code with the folder of the mounted drive. 
2. Edit and save a file (unfortunately, I can I only get this to happen sporadically. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't... and I can't seem to find a pattern for it)
3. The following error messages show up:
"Failed to save 'examplefile.js': The content on disk is newer. Click on Compare to compare your version with the one on disk."

And then when I click "Compare":
"Unable to open 'examplefile.js (on disk) ↔ examplefile.js (in Visual Studio Code)': Could not resolve any model with provided uri.."

I hope this was helpful, and if there is currently any resolution to this, I would like to know. It has only been happening since I updated to 1.8.0. It has made VSC unusable for me on my current project (and I really love VSC, its been great).

EDIT: I included a couple of screenshots. It seems to happen with any type of files, but I gave this one as an example.

![screen shot 2016-12-15 at 4 50 48 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7053830/21243397/aad50ce6-c2e6-11e6-8c45-9fa6006c5fe6.png)
![screen shot 2016-12-15 at 4 50 56 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7053830/21243401/afadff98-c2e6-11e6-97a4-7e67b5b05405.png)
